184921761.review:
Let me start off by saying that this game is entirely playable by installing a couple of fanmade patches. You can find all of the instructions and links in this guide: [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2038838545]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2038838545[/url] It is very easy to do and only takes about 5 minutes. I did this before my first playthrough and experienced zero performance issues.

As a huge fan of Lightning Returns, I figured it was about time I played this game as well. Boy am I glad I finally did. Serah and Noel are genuinely great characters and its fun to watch their interactions throughout the game. I always found myself looking forward to unlocking the next areas just to see their reactions. The story is a little generic at parts but I loved every bit of it. Even after playing Lightning Returns multiple times, I was still surprised by this game's ending

The combat is also great; I was weary at first since I had played a bit of XIII in the past and really disliked the combat. This game seemed to have fixed the issues in XIII (such as slow paradigm shifts and little customization) and added some extra improvements, like being able to capture monsters and add them to your team. 

The Crystarium leveling system makes grinding more rewarding in my opinion. Its fun to go through a bunch of battles and see how many points you racked up to level up your team. Not to mention the addition of fragment skills that allow you to manipulate factors such as how frequently you encounter enemies or how often rare enemies appear. The schemata system is also effective and easy to understand.

My only real negatives with this game are the side quests and anomaly puzzles. Many of the side quests are fetch quests that require you to find and return an item. These quickly get repetitive and boring. The anomaly puzzles are a fun addition, but I found the clock puzzles to be too difficult and ended up using an online tool to complete them.

I highly recommend this game even if you have not played any of the XIII entries. The story is easy to follow, the characters are lovable, the combat is fun, the environments are beautiful, and the soundtrack is amazing. Lightning Returns is one of my favorite games of all time and this might just be a close second after completing it. Just install the patches and you're good to go!

184690888.review:
I deeply, unironically love this game. It is pilled high with reasons not to, a few big ones which may turn you off could be:

The game requires external patching to get running stably because Square Enix don't understand how to port to PC, and this is from the early era of there ports so they also didn't care very much about the PC market.
The plot is absolutely insane, character motivations are simplistic and often pulled straight from the JRPG trope bin with little thought or care.
100%ing the game requires a lot of tedious side-quests which should have been cut entirely.

So why do I recommend it?

This game lets have the most fun with the paradigm system because it is unlocked from the start. You get build a pack of swap-able monsters who take up the third slot so shifting paradigms also can shift an entire party member. There is a lot of depth here, in terms of how you level your characters and what monsters you use, level up and when you should infuse them into newer monsters to pass on key passive or active skills. It becomes a fun little game play loop.

The music, while atypical of final fantasy in several places, showed a willingness to experiment with genres and sounds in a Square game (something they are normally unwilling to do) and the visual design is solid for a game from 2011. Is the faux-death metal boss encounter theme for everyone? No, but I love that they tried.

I also like the plot. It's terrible but in a bizarrely charming way because you know all the hilarious or ironic moments are unintentional. This isn't a shit writer claiming that writing a bad story intentionally makes it good and then claiming that their one ironic idea justifies a bland experience. This is a team of writers who tell you straight faced that if you change the future you change the past because of time travel. Or that if you scream loud enough in the future someone in the past will hear you and change their perspective. 

And so, you laugh. 

You laugh because the professional voice actors intone the most non-nonsensical gibberish with the solemnity of a grand Shakespearean drama and that the writers at Square thought that this was, if not great, then at least compelling or good rather than stupid. And that complete lack of awareness, or unprofessional delivery from the actors, make it oddly compelling. You want to see way insane train of logic your characters jump on because the writers didn't know how to write a time travel story. You want to see how fumbling and awkward the dialogue can get because they introduced the most basic of dialogue selection during non-essential conversations and they filled with bizarre anime answers.

So buy it one sale, install the 4G patch so the memory leak doesn't cause the game the crash and enjoy.

183899401.review:
[h2]Ein wahrscheinlich recht gutes Spiel, jedoch ein extrem schlechter Port[/h2]

Nachdem ich "Final Fantasy XIII" beendet habe und mir das Spiel doch sehr gefallen hat, wollte ich dementsprechend den direkten Nachfolger der Trilogie "Final Fantasy XIII-2" spielen.

Ich habe mich sehr auf das Spiel gefreut, und war auch am Anfang ziemlich positiv gestimmt, da das Spiel sehr spannend anfing.
Auch einige Gameplay-Mechaniken aus dem ersten Teil der Trilogie wurden überarbeitet und erweitert. So wirkte die Welt deutlich größer und belebter, man kann die Welt regelrecht ein bisschen erkunden. Es ist daher nicht so wie in "Final Fantasy XIII" wo die meisten Passagen der Welt wie eine strikte Line aufgebaut sind und man sie nur abläuft.

Auch die Aufmachung und der Anfang der Story gefielen mir eigentlich.


[h3]Technische Probleme[/h3]

Das Spiel war super... naja... bis die technischen Probleme des schlechten PC-Ports anfingen.
Ursprünglich ist das Spiel für die Konsolen erschienen. Erst ein paar Jahre später wurde das Spiel daraufhin auf den PC geportet.

Die erste Stunde des Spiels lief alles problemlos. Als jedoch der Prolog endete und Kapital 1 eingeleitet wurde, gab es bei mir die ersten Probleme. Ich selber konnte nicht mehr manuell speichern, da es quasi ein Münzwurf war ob das Spiel während des Speichervorgangs abstürzen wird oder nicht.

Nachdem ich Kapital 1 beendet habe, war es aber endgültig vorbei. An dem Punkt stürzte das Spiel permanent nur noch ab. Nicht nur während des Speicherns, auch beim Wechseln der einzelnen Szenen.
Ab hier ist es nativ leider gar nicht mehr spielbar.

Selbst die Performance im Spiel ist miserable, aber ich würde dort wenigstens ein Auge zudrücken, wenn das Spiel einfach spielbar wäre.


[h3]Fazit[/h3]

Ob das Spiel wirklich gut ist - ob die Story gut ist, kann ich leider nicht einschätzen.
Ich hätte es aber liebend gern herausgefunden.

183843488.review:
Let's talk about the elephant in the room. FF-13-2 is a horrendous PC port, this game absolutely will not work out of the box without applying fan fixes and mods. Without fixes it'll likely crash either during most cut-scenes or just crash every 10-15 minutes.  

There's a guide on steam with a list of all fixes to get the game running on modern hardware and with those installed I only had a single crash in all my time playing, then rarely a brief stutter when loading into a new area for the 1st time.

If you correctly apply the fan fixes and get the game working then I would argue that FF13-2 is one of if not the most underrated FF game, it fixes practically every major issue I had with 13.

The game maps are no longer 90% straight corridors and completely linear for 30+ hours.

You don't instantly game over if the party leader is downed.

Monsters actually drop gil now when you beat them.

13-2 doesn't take an additional 5+ hours of grinding the same 6 second fight over and over to max out all characters after you've 100% the rest of the game.

The pacing is no longer abyssal, in FF-13 you don't unlock paradigm shifting until chapter 3, many hours into the story, in 13-2 you start with it unlocked straight away.

13-2 features Loads of varied side quests and activities instead of just the 64 stone battles and I guess the chocobo treasure hunts seen in 13.

13-2 features a monster taming & training system where you can capture most enemies you encounter who act as your 3rd party member.

The main antagonist is fantastic, easily one of the best written in the whole series. 

I personally wasn't a big fan of the FF-13 OST, it has a few amazing songs but in general it's very whelming.  13-2 has one of the best soundtracks of the series with banger after banger.


It's a real shame how bad of a port this game is cause overall FF-13-2 is a really good game, it's a massive improvement over FF-13 but players should not be expected to need mods and fan patches to run a relatively recent game publish by bloody Square Enix.
